subject: Mathematics
objectives: Classify data types, choose sampling methods, and present data effectively
Calculate and interpret measures of central tendency and dispersion
Apply probability rules and basic distributions to real decisions

lessons.title: Data Collection and Presentation
lessons.text: **Data** can be **qualitative** (categories) or **quantitative** (numerical). Quantitative data may be **discrete** (counts) or **continuous** (measurements). Good **sampling** (random, stratified, systematic) reduces bias and improves validity. Data are presented using **tables**, **bar charts**, **pie charts**, **histograms**, and **line graphs**. In Ghana, sources include the **Ghana Statistical Service (GSS)** and school surveys. Accurate presentation helps reveal trends in population, agriculture yield, or market prices. Choosing the right chart depends on the data type and the message you want to convey.

lessons.title: Measures of Central Tendency and Dispersion
lessons.text: Measures of **central tendency** (mean, median, mode) summarize the centre of data. **Dispersion** (range, interquartile range, variance, **standard deviation**) shows spread. The mean is sensitive to outliers, while median is robust. Standard deviation indicates how far values typically deviate from the mean. In comparing schools or regions in Ghana, both centre and spread matter—small differences in means may be unimportant if variability is large.

lessons.title: Probability and Distributions
lessons.text: **Probability** quantifies chance between 0 and 1. For independent events A and B, P(A∩B) = P(A)P(B); for mutually exclusive events, P(A∪B)=P(A)+P(B). Counting with **combinations** supports binomial outcomes. The **normal distribution** is bell-shaped, often used to model test scores around a mean. Probability informs decisions in agriculture (rainfall), sports (match outcomes), and business (demand).
